en.value: I'm from Russia. Do you speak Russian?
Select the form of "to be" that goes with "we".
This sentence requires a question mark.
We ask this to find out where someone comes from.
Saying where we come from and our nationality - Verb "to be" in questions
Yeah, that's right. And you? Where [k]do you come[/k] from?

Paul is trying to guess where Elena is from!

"guess" = guess
Type the question with a similar meaning to "Where are you from?".
In this lesson, we will learn how to form questions with the verb "to be". Look at the examples below.
Where do you come from? - I come from Turkey.
He comes from Spain. He is [k]Spanish[/k].

You can also say "Where do you come from?" and "I come from...". They are both widely used and mean the same as "Where are you from?" and "I'm from...".
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.

Click on the different forms of the verb "to be" in the sentences below.
Cool! So do you speak both Russian and [k]English[/k]?
Read and listen to the words.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I'm from [k]Russia[/k], but my mother is English.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
We already know how to talk about the languages we speak. Now we'll learn how to answer the question "Where are you from?", learning some names of countries as we go.
We are from France. We speak French.
When we form questions that contain the verb “to be”, we simply take the verb and place it at the beginning of the sentence, like this:
You are from Spain. - Are you from Spain?
She is from Spain. She speaks Spanish.

We already know the names of some languages. In the table below there are some names of countries with their corresponding nationalities and language names. Notice that languages and nationalities are often (but not always!) the same.
Select the form of the verb "to be" that you hear.
Where are you from? - I am from Russia.
I [k]come from[/k] Brazil. I speak [k]Portuguese[/k] and a bit of Spanish.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.

[k]Where do you come from?[/k] I'm from England.
